dc:description: ANK1 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS) in 1996 (Eber, PMID: 8640229). HS is characterized by the presence of spherical-shaped erythrocytes, termed spherocytes, on a peripheral blood smear. Spherocytes can accumulate in the spleen, causing anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Complications include hyperbilirubinemia in neonates, cholelithiasis, hemolytic episodes, aplastic crises, and iron overload, although mild cases may go undetected without a blood smear. Spherocytosis, Type 1 (OMIM:182900) is associated with ANK1  with both autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive forms of HS having been reported. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we have split these two inheritance patterns for gene-disease validity curation. The dominant form of Spherocytosis, Type 1 (OMIM:182900) was curated separately and reached Definitive and the mechanism of pathogenicity is known to be loss of function of ANK, leading to a loss of flexibility and shape of the erythrocyte membrane. For the recessive form, for 3/7 families, only one allele or two in cis alleles was reported. At least 7 variants (missense, deep intronic, and promoter variants) have been reported in humans (PMIDs: 8640229, 11102985, 17327413, 16037067). However, 4 of these variants (including the commonly reported c.127-39509T>C (c.-108T-C) variant) are too frequent in gnomAD to cause disease (ranging from 0.2% to 11% allele frequency). These frequent variants were present in 5/7 families. In the families with recessive inheritance claimed, most heterozygous parents, when available for phenotyping, were actually mildly affected with features of HS, contradicting a pure recessive form of inheritance. In summary, evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes minimal case-level data (2/7 families are scored) and the only functional evidence includes gene expression consistent with the location of disease (PMID: 2139228).In conclusion, while the experts felt that there could exist hypomorphic alleles that have mild enough effect to lead to disease only when found on both alleles, the experts felt that there was insufficient evidence for a pure recessive form of this gene-disease relationship with existing cases more likely explained by a dosage effect of pathogenic variants. A Limited classification was approved by the ClinGen General Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date June 23, 2021 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: While the mouse model confirmed that the promoter variant present in the proband led to decreased ANK1 expression and defective binding of the TATA binding protein, no phenotypic analysis was done.
evidence.rdfs:label: Transgenic Mouse

evidence.dc:description: In normal mice, erythrocyte ghosts were prepared and western blots were performed. ANK1 was found to be expressed in the cell membrane fraction (which is what the ghost procedure isolates) of RBCs.
evidence.rdfs:label: ANK1 erythrocyte expression

evidence.dc:description: The c.127-39509T>C (legacy c.-108T>C) has been identified in 11% of African alleles in gnomAD (with 65 homozygous observations). The p.Val463Ile variant is present in 0.2% of Finnish alleles in gnomAD (4 homozygous observations total in gnomAD).

evidence.rdfs:label: SK
evidence.detectionMethod: All 42 coding exons of ankyrin-1 and all 19 coding exons of band 3 were amplified by PCR
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: No further phenotypic information was provided

evidence.dc:description: The c.127-39509T>C (legacy c.-108C>T) has been identified in 11% of African alleles in gnomAD (including 65 homozygotes).

amplified by PCR
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Severity of HS was not provided. No further phenotypes.

evidence.dc:description: The c.127-39509T>C (legacy nomenclature c.-108T>C) is present in 11% of African alleles in gnomAD with 65 homozygous observations.

evidence.rdfs:label: MT
evidence.detectionMethod: All 42 coding exons of ankyrin-1 and all 19 coding exons of band 3 were amplified by PCR

evidence.dc:description: The variants were identified in cis, which does not suggest an AR MOI, although the authors claim it does. The c.127-39509T>C (legacy c.-108T>C) is present in 11% of African alleles in gnomAD (including 65 homozygous observations). The c.127-39554G>A (legacy c.-153G>A) variant is present in 2% of African alleles with 3 homozygous observations.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 3
evidence.detectionMethod: All 42 exons and the promoter region of ANK1 were amplified by PCR
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: No further phenotypic information was provided.

member.rdfs:label: Edelman_Proband
member.detectionMethod:
DNA was amplified using primers for the coding exons and promoter of ANK1. Then DHPLC was performed and nucleotide sequence was determined on amplification
products demonstrating an abnormal chromatograph.
member.previousTestingDescription: SSCP and heteroduplex analysis of ANK1 did not yield any variants.

evidence.dc:description: The c.127-39509T>C (legacy c.-108T>C) variant is present in 11% of African alleles in gnomAD (including 65 homozygous observations). The c.5544+91C>T (legacy c.5703+16C>T) has been identified in 4.4% of Finnish alleles in gnomAD (including 30 homozygous observations).

evidence.rdfs:label: FG
evidence.detectionMethod: All 42 coding exons of ankyrin-1 and all 19 coding exons of band 3 were amplified by PCR
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: No further phenotypic information is provided

evidence.dc:description: A transgenic mouse model and additional experiments were performed to determine the effect of the promoter variant. It was determined that it led to decreased expression of ANK1.

The variant is absent from gnomAD with adequate coverage. Mini gene and reticulocyte RNA assays demonstrate that the variant causes 11 mutant spliceoforms, but no WT product. I downgraded for a homozygous variant in a consanguineous family.
